lesson.name: Lesson 4.10 Teacher Guide: Graphing a Function Using Transformations

page.title: 4.10.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, students work to graph functions in slope-intercept form using transformations. They will identify vertical shifts, vertical stretches and compressions, and vertical rotations.

Through exploration with graphing, students will recognize patterns for the transformations and understand how the constants in the slope-intercept form determine the transformations needed to graph the function.

Students will also be able to describe how one function transforms from the parent function, f(x)=x and how one function transforms to another.

Learning Goals (Teacher Facing)

Students will be able to:

  • Use slope-intercept form and transformations to graph linear functions.
  • Recognize the shifts made to a parent linear function to form another linear function.

Learning Targets (Student Facing)

  • Use slope-intercept form and transformations to graph linear functions.
  • Recognize the shifts made to a parent linear function to form another linear function.

Texas Essential Knowledge and Skills (TEKs)


TEKS

\(A3(E)\) determine the effects on the graph of the parent function \(f(x) = x\) when \(f(x)\) is replaced by \(af(x)\), \(f(x) + d\), \(f(x - c)\), \(f(bx)\) for specific values of \(a\), \(b\), \(c\), and \(d\);

Full coverage: Lesson provides content that covers all parts of this TEKS.

Students will also complete a series of problems in the 4.10.5: Practice.

  • Encourage students to use key vocabulary words in “math talk” and their written and oral explanations.
  • Utilize a word wall. Sample cards are located here: Mathematics Vocabulary Word Wall Cards

Vocabulary words that are emphasized in this lesson include:

New Vocabulary

  • vertical shift

page.title: 4.10.1: Graphing Linear Functions
page.contents:
Warm Up (10 minutes)


This warm-up recalls how to graph linear functions and which lines are parallel or perpendicular. It also introduces how one linear function can be shifted to another.

Later in the lesson, students will graph linear functions only using knowledge of transformations to prepare them for later units when they graph other functions with transformations.

For students who can benefit from a more accessible model, use geoboards and rubber bands. Use one color rubber band for the \(x\)- and \(y\)-axes. Use a different color for each line graphed. Work with students to count spots on the geoboard and discuss the graphs and their relationships.

Launch

Arrange students in groups of 2. Allow students to compare their graphs with their partners and discuss the relationships of the lines. 

Student-Facing Statement

On your coordinate grid, use the slope and \(y\)-intercept of each equation to graph each equation.

Use a different color for each equation.

  • \(y=3x +4\)
  • \(y=3x - 2\)
  • \(y=\frac13 x +1\)
  • \(y=-\frac13 x -3\)

Use the graphing tool here or technology outside the course.



  1. What is the relationship between lines \(a\) and \(b\)?
  2. What is the relationship between lines \(b\) and \(d\)?
  3. How many vertical spaces are between lines \(a\) and \(b\)?

Student Response


  1. They are parallel lines.
  2. They are perpendicular lines.
  3. 6

Activity Synthesis

Invite students to share their interpretations of the given equations and the new equations they wrote. Then, discuss with students:

  • “Do you notice any other relationships between pairs of lines?”
  • “How many vertical spaces are between lines \(a\) and \(b\)?”

page.title: 4.10.2: Vertical Shifts
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity prompts students to look at how the \(y\)-intercept in slope-intercept form affects the graph of a linear function. Circulate to ensure students are graphing their lines properly. If necessary, partner students during the graphing process.

In pairs, students should discuss the vertical shifts to the parent function, \(f(x)=x\), to graph the new functions.

Launch

Ask students if they have ever played a board game. Connect rolling dice and moving that number of spots to the number of spots a line can shift up the graph.

For students who can benefit from a more accessible model, use geoboards and rubber bands. Use one color rubber band for the \(x\)- and \(y\)-axes. Use a different color for each line graphed. Work with students to count spots on the geoboard and discuss the graphs and their relationships.

Student-Facing Statement

On the same coordinate grid, graph the following linear functions. Use a different color for each:

  • \(f(x)=x+4\)
  • \(f(x)=x+2\)
  • \(f(x)=x\)
  • \(f(x)=x-2\)
  • \(f(x)=x-4\)

Compare your graph to the one below:

  1. What is slope of each line?
  1. How can the parent function, \(f(x)=x\), be shifted to overlap \(f(x)=x+2\)?
  1. How can the parent function, \(f(x)=x\), be shifted to overlap \(f(x)=x-4\)?


    • \(f(x)=x+4\)
    • \(f(x)=x+2\)
    • \(f(x)=x\)
    • \(f(x)=x-2\)
    • \(f(x)=x-4\)

What changed with these functions? How did this change their graphs?

In \(f(x)=mx+b\), the \(b\) acts as the vertical shift. This is a type of transformation to the graph of \(f(x)=x\). The vertical shift “transforms” the parent function into another function.

Student Response

  1. 1
  2. Shift up 2
  3. Shift down 4
  4. Sample Response:
    The constant added to or subtracted from x changed. When a number was added to x, it shifted the line up that many units. When a number was subtracted from x, it shifted the line down that many units..

Activity Synthesis

Invite students to create other questions for students to answer about how much one linear function must shift to get to another.

4.10.2: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION: What transformation takes place from the graph of \(y=4x-3\) to \(y=4x +5\)?

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

Down 8

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: For the second function to move down, there would be a negative change. The answer is up 8.

Right 8

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: In \(y=mx+b\), the \(b\) describes the vertical shift. The answer is up 8.

Up 8

That’s correct! Check yourself: In the two equations, the \(b\), or \(y\)-intercept of \(y=mx+b\), changes. This determines the vertical change. From –3 to 5 is a vertical shift up 8.

Left 8

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The \(y\)-intercept changing signifies a vertical change. The answer is up 8.

4.10.2: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Vertical Shifts and \(y\)-Intercepts

In the equation \(f(x)=mx+b\):

  • \(b\) is the \(y\)-intercept of the graph and indicates the point \((0,b)\) at which the graph crosses the \(y\)-axis.
  • \(m\) is the slope of the line and indicates the vertical displacement (rise) and horizontal displacement (run) between each successive pair of points.

The \(y\)-intercept tells where the parent function, \(f(x)=x\), has shifted up or down.

Example 1:

Tell how \(f(x)=x+7\) has shifted from the parent function \(f(x)=x\).
Since \(b=7\), the \(y\)-intercept is +7, so the graph shifts up 7 from the parent function.

Example 2:

Tell how \(f(x)=x-9\) has shifted from the parent function \(f(x)=x\).
Since \(b=-9\), the \(y\)-intercept is –9, so the graph shifts down 9 from the parent function.

Try It: Vertical Shifts and \(y\)-Intercepts

Tell the shift made to \(f(x)=x\) to arrive at \(f(x)=x - 4\).

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to find the shift made to \(f(x)=x\):

Since the \(b\) of slope-intercept form is –4, this is also the \(y\)-intercept. Therefore, the graph of \(f(x)=x\) is shifted down 4 to arrive at \(f(x)=x-4\).

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 4.10.3: Vertical Stretches and Compressions
page.contents:
Activity (20 minutes)

This activity prompts students to look at how the slope in slope-intercept form affects the graph of a linear function. Circulate to ensure students are graphing their lines properly. If necessary, partner students during the graphing process.

In pairs, students should discuss the vertical shifts to the parent function, \(f(x)=x\), to graph the new functions.

Launch

Allow students to work in pairs to check each other’s graphs and discuss the relationships to answer the questions. During class discussion, solicit a pair for each question to describe the effects the different slopes have on the graphs.

For students who can benefit from a more accessible model, use geoboards and rubber bands. Use one color rubber band for the \(x\)- and \(y\)-axes. Use a different color for each line graphed. Work with students to count spots on the geoboard and discuss the graphs and their relationships.

Student-Facing Statement



  1. On the same coordinate grid, graph the following linear functions. Use a different color for each:
    1. \( f(x)=3x\)
    2. \( f(x)=2x\)
    3. \(f(x)=x\)

  2. What do you notice about the slopes of lines \(a\), \(b\), and \(c\) as the number gets larger?

  3. Now, graph lines \(d\) and \(e\) on the same graph as \(a\)–\(c\), but use different colors.
    1. \(f(x)=\frac12 x\)
    2. \( f(x)=\frac13 x\)

  4. How does line \(d\) compare to line \(b\)? What can you say about the lines when \(m<1\)?

  5. Now graph lines \(f\), \(g\), and \(h\) on the same coordinate grid as \(a\)–\(e\), but use different colors.
    1. \(f(x)=-\frac12 x\)
    2. \(f(x)=-x\)
    3. \(f(x)=-2x\)

  6. What changed with these functions? How did this change their graphs?

In the equation \(f(x)=mx\), the \(m\) is acting as the vertical stretch or vertical compression of the identity function. When \(m\) is negative, there is also a vertical reflection of the graph.

Multiplying the equation of \(f(x)=x\) by \(m\) stretches the graph of \(f\) by a factor of \(m\) units if \(m>1\) and compresses the graph of \(f\) by a factor of \(m\) units if \(0<m<1\). This means the larger the absolute value of \(m\), the steeper the slope.

Video: Identifying Vertical Stretches and Compressions

Watch the following video to learn more about vertical stretches and compressions.



Student Response



  2. As the coefficient increases, the line gets steeper.


  4. As the coefficient gets smaller, the line is less steep.


  6. There is a negative coefficient. This reflected the positive version of the line over the \(x\)-axis.

Activity Synthesis

Explain to students that graphing linear functions using transformations will assist them as you move to graphing different function families in the future.

4.10.3: Self Check

After the activity, students will answer the following question to check their understanding of the concepts explored in the activity.

QUESTION: How does the graph of \(f(x)=\frac14 x -3\) change from the parent function, \(f(x)=x\)?

ANSWERS

FEEDBACK

Vertical stretch of \(\frac14\), down 3

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: A slope less than 1 signifies a vertical compression. The answer is vertical compression of \(\frac14\), down 3.

Vertical compression of \(\frac14\), down 3

That’s correct! Check yourself: The slope is \(\frac14\), which is less than 1, so there is a vertical compression. The \(y\)-intercept is –3, so there is a vertical shift down 3.

Vertical compression of \(\frac14\), up 3

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: The \(y\)-intercept is negative. The answer is vertical compression of \(\frac14\), down 3.

Vertical stretch of \(\frac14\), left 3

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: A slope less than 1 signifies a vertical compression, and the \(y\)-intercept gives the vertical shift. The answer is vertical compression of \(\frac14\), down 3.

4.10.3: Additional Resources

The following content is available to students who would like more support based on their experience with the self check. Students will not automatically have access to this content, so you may wish to share it with those who could benefit from it.

Transformations of Linear Functions

Given the equation of a linear function, use transformations to graph the linear function in the form \(f(x)=mx+b\).

  1. Graph \(f(x)=x\).
  2. Vertically stretch or compress the graph by a factor \(m\).
  3. Shift the graph up or down \(b\) units.

Graph \(f(x)=12x−3\) using transformations.

The equation for the function shows that \(m=12\), so the identity function is vertically compressed by 12. The equation for the function also shows that \(b=−3\), so the identity function is vertically shifted down 3 units. First, graph the identity function, and show the vertical compression as in Figure 16.

This graph shows two functions on an \((x, y)\) coordinate plane. One shows an increasing function of \(y = x\) divided by 2 that runs through the points \((0, 0)\) and \((2, 1)\). The second shows an increasing function of \(y = x\) and runs through the points \((0, 0)\) and \((1, 1)\).

Now, show the vertical shift:

This graph shows two functions on an \((x, y)\) coordinate plane. The first is an increasing function of \(y = x\) divided by 2 and runs through the points \((0, 0)\) and \((2, 1)\). The second shows an increasing function of \(y = x\) divided by 2 minus 3 and passes through the points \((0, 3)\) and \((2, -2)\). An arrow pointing downward from the first function to the second function reveals the vertical shift.

Can we sketch a graph by reversing the order of the transformations?

No. The order of the transformations follows the order of operations. When the function is evaluated at a given input, the corresponding output is calculated by following the order of operations. So, the stretch was performed before the vertical shift.


Try It: Transformations of Linear Functions

Name the transformations to go from the parent function, \(f(x)=x\), to \(f(x)=4+2x\).

In your notebook, write down your answer. Then select the Solution button to check your work.

Solution

Here is how to determine the transformations:

First, the slope, \(m=2\), tells that there is a vertical stretch of 2.

Next, the \(y\)-intercept is 4, so there is a vertical shift up 2.

How did you do? Know that you learn more from wrong answers than from right answers! Wrong answers help us find flaws in our thinking. Take a minute to think about why you got the question wrong. Then you won’t get this type of question wrong again!

page.title: 4.10.4: Graphing Using Transformations
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)


Student-Facing Statement

Match each equation of the linear functions with one of the lines in the given graph.

  1. \(f(x)=2x+3\)
  2. \(g(x)=2x−3\)
  3. \(h(x)=−2x+3\)
  4. \(j(x)=\frac12x+3\)

Student Response

  1. I
  2. III
  3. IV
  4. II

Response to Student Thinking

More Chances

Students will have more opportunities to understand the mathematical ideas in this cool-down, so there is no need to slow down or add additional work to the next lessons. Instead, use the results of this cool-down to provide guidance for what to look for and emphasize over the next several lessons to support students in advancing their current understanding.

page.title: 4.10.5: Practice
page.contents:
Students will complete the following questions to practice the skills they have learned in this lesson.

Use the graph below to answer #1–3

  1. Tell the shift from \(j(x)=2x-6\) to \(f(x)=2x+3\).
    1. Down 3
    2. Down 8
    3. Up 9
    4. Up 8

ANSWER: Up 9

  1. Tell the transformations from \(f(x)=2x+3\) to \(h(x)=-2x+2\).
    1. Vertical reflection, up 1
    2. Vertical reflection, down 1
    3. Vertical stretch, right 1
    4. Vertical stretch, left 1

ANSWER: b. Vertical reflection, down 1

  1. Describe the transformations made from the parent linear function to achieve \(g(x)=\frac12 x -4\).

    Select all that apply:
    1. Vertical stretch of \(\frac12\)
    2. Vertical compression of \(\frac12\)
    3. Up 4
    4. Down 4
    5. Right 4
    6. Left 4

ANSWERS: Vertical compression of \(\frac12\); Down 4




  1. What are the equations of the two lines shown?

    Select all that apply:
    1. \(y=x+4\)
    2. \(y=x-4\)
    3. \(y= -\frac32 x+1\)
    4. \(y=\frac32 x +7\)
    5. \(y= \frac32x+1\)
    6. \(y=-\frac32x+7\)

ANSWERS: \(y= -\frac32 x+1\), \(y= -\frac32 x+7\)

  1. The linear function \(f(x)=x\) has a vertical stretch of 3, a vertical reflection, and a vertical shift down 4. Which of the following is the new function?
    1. \(f(x)=3x+4\)
    2. \(f(x)=-3x+4\)
    3. \(f(x)=3x-4\)
    4. \(f(x)=-3x-4\)

ANSWER: \(f(x)=-3x-4\)

  1. The linear function \(f(x)=x\) has a vertical compression of \(\frac13\) and a vertical shift up 2. Which of the following is the new function?
    1. \(f(x)=\frac13x +2\)
    2. \(f(x)=-\frac13 +2\)
    3. \(f(x)=2x+\frac13\)
    4. \(f(x)=2x - \frac13\)

ANSWER: \(f(x)=\frac13 x +2\)

  1. What is the equation of the function graphed?

    1. \(y= 3x +7\)
    2. \(y= \frac34 x+7\)
    3. \(y=- \frac34 x +7\)
    4. \(y= -\frac34x+7\)

ANSWER: \(y=- \frac34 x +7\)

  1. The linear function \(f(x)=x\) has a vertical compression of \(\frac13\) and a vertical shift down 2. Which of the following is the new function?
    1. \(f(x)=\frac13x -2\)
    2. \(f(x)=-\frac13-2\)
    3. \(f(x)=2x+\frac13\)
    4. \(f(x)=2x - \frac13\)

ANSWER: \(f(x)=\frac13 x -2\)

page.title: 4.10.6: Lesson Synthesis
page.contents:
Some key takeaways from this lesson are that parts of linear functions can be used to determine how graphs of linear functions can be transformed.

To help students see these points, discuss questions such as:

  • Describe how a linear function, such as \(f(x)=4x-1\), can be graphed using the \(y\)-intercept and then the slope and also how it can be graphed using transformations.
  • Do the same for \(y=-\frac14 x +3\).

Tell students that expressions, equations, and inequalities are mathematical models. A model is a mathematical representation of a real-life situation. When people create models, they rely on the information they have, but they also make assumptions and decisions that affect the models. If the information or assumptions change, the model would also change.
